| ( [![Beartrap.png](/images/c/cf/Beartrap.png)](/wiki/File:Beartrap.png) |                                  |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------- |
| Name                                                                    | beartrap                         |
| Appearance                                                              | beartrap                         |
| Base price                                                              | 60 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid") |
| Weight                                                                  | [200](/wiki/Weight "Weight")     |
| Material                                                                | [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron")        |
| Monster use                                                             | *Will not be used by monsters.*  |

A **beartrap** is a [tool](/wiki/Tool "Tool") object that can be used to create a **bear trap** (^ [![Bear trap.png](/images/7/72/Bear_trap.png)](/wiki/File:Bear_trap.png)) on the ground. This is a [trap](/wiki/Trap "Trap") that will clamp onto any monster or adventurer unfortunate enough to stumble onto it, dealing 2d4 damage.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

The beartrap item is usually obtained by [untrapping](/wiki/Untrap "Untrap") a live bear trap. These can be [applied](/wiki/Apply "Apply") on the ground to create a [trap](/wiki/Trap "Trap") to clamp onto hapless monsters, rendering them immobile until they escape. Monsters that are too [small](/wiki/Monster_size "Monster size"), [amorphous](/wiki/Amorphous "Amorphous"), [whirly](/wiki/Whirly "Whirly"), [unsolid](/wiki/Unsolid "Unsolid") or [flying](/wiki/Flying "Flying") won't be trapped, and [metallivores](/wiki/Metallivore "Metallivore") can eat the trap. Be careful, as you can still get caught in your own bear trap if you step on it or fail to disarm it.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Becoming trapped](#Becoming_trapped)
- [2 Escaping](#Escaping)
- [3 Disarming](#Disarming)
- [4 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [5 History](#History)
- [6 Messages](#Messages)
- [7 References](#References)

## Becoming trapped

You will escape a bear trap under the following circumstances:

- If you are [levitating](/wiki/Levitation "Levitation") or [flying](/wiki/Flying "Flying"), you will avoid the trap. If the trap is hidden, it will not be revealed.
- If you are polymorphed into a form that is [amorphous](/wiki/Amorphous "Amorphous"), [whirly](/wiki/Whirly "Whirly") or [unsolid](/wiki/Unsolid "Unsolid"), you will avoid the trap.
- If you are polymorphed into a form that is *tiny* or *small*, and you are not riding a steed, you will avoid the trap.

If none of these apply, you have a 4⁄5 chance of avoiding the bear trap if you are already aware of it and are not [fumbling](/wiki/Fumbling "Fumbling"). Otherwise, you are caught.

Being caught in a bear trap renders you unable to move, in addition to the damage it deals. When caught in a bear trap, you are unable to [kick](/wiki/Kick "Kick"). During this time, you still can attack and be attacked.

If you trigger the trap when riding, it affects your steed instead of you. Monsters can be trapped too.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

## Escaping

The ordinary way to escape a bear trap is to try to move out of it. For some reason, trying to move diagonally is most effective, allowing you to escape in 4–7 moves;[\[3\]](#cite_note-3) this will move you diagonally out of the trap even if a wall is in the way. Attempting to move orthogonally requires about five times as many moves to escape.

Another way to escape from a bear trap is to use [teleport](/wiki/Teleport "Teleport"), [level teleport](/wiki/Level_teleport "Level teleport"), or [branchport](/wiki/Branchport "Branchport") to move yourself away from it. You can also polymorph yourself into a form that cannot be held by a bear trap, due to size or body composition.

Zapping a [wand of opening](/wiki/Wand_of_opening "Wand of opening") or casting [knock](/wiki/Knock "Knock") downward will instantly release you.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

Finally, it is possible to [jump](/wiki/Jump "Jump") out of a bear trap. This carries a penalty, however: you will take *d10* damage and suffer [wounded legs](/wiki/Wounded_legs "Wounded legs") for 500–1499 turns.

Oddly, [beartraps]() reset themselves after someone escapes from them.

## Disarming

Once you know the location of a bear trap, you can attempt to [#untrap](/wiki/Untrap "Untrap") it. You cannot disarm a bear trap that is holding you, so you must escape the trap first. When you attempt to disarm the trap, there is a chance that you will be accidentally caught in it instead. If you successfully disarm the trap, it will be replaced by a beartrap item on the ground.

It is also possible to remove a bear trap by eating it, if you are [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into a [metallivore](/wiki/Metallivore "Metallivore"). Unlike untrapping, you can eat a bear trap that is holding you, and there is no chance of accidentally triggering the trap. However, eating the trap will obviously not produce a beartrap item.

## Strategy

A beartrap can be applied in a narrow corridor to slow down pursuers. They can be used when [stealing from shops](/wiki/Stealing_from_shops "Stealing from shops") to prevent the [shopkeeper](/wiki/Shopkeeper "Shopkeeper") from blocking the [door](/wiki/Door "Door"). A stuck monster is also an easy target for [ranged attacks](/wiki/Ranged_attack "Ranged attack").

It takes some time to set a beartrap—if a hostile monster comes near, you will stop setting the trap (in much the same way an approaching monster can interrupt a meal). It may help to retreat around a corner or down a long passage to give yourself time to apply the trap. Because of the time delay in setting the trap, it does not make a very useful tool for emergency getaways. The time needed to set the trap is doubled if you are [blind](/wiki/Blind "Blind").

Trying to set a beartrap while [fumbling](/wiki/Fumbling "Fumbling"), or setting a [cursed](/wiki/Cursed "Cursed") beartrap has a chance of getting you stuck in the beartrap. The chance is modified by [Luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck"); if your Luck is maxed, the chances are very slim. Setting a beartrap while [riding](/wiki/Riding "Riding") a steed with [Unskilled](/wiki/Skill "Skill") in Riding has the same chance of failure, and an even worse chance if also fumbling or using a cursed beartrap; however, failing on a steed simply results in the beartrap item falling to the floor harmlessly.

A beartrap (the item) can be [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") as normal; the 'bear trap' (the trap) is not affected by polymorph.

## History

The bear trap object first appeared in [NetHack 3.2.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.2.0 "NetHack 3.2.0").

## Messages

- A bear trap closes on your \<foot>!

  You triggered a bear trap.

- You are released from the bear trap.

  The bear trap is no longer holding you.

- \<monster> is caught in a bear trap!

  A monster triggered a bear trap.

- You hear the roaring of an angry bear!

  An unseen [owlbear](/wiki/Owlbear "Owlbear") or [bugbear](/wiki/Bugbear "Bugbear") just triggered a bear trap.

- You howl in anger!

  You triggered a bear trap while polymorphed into an owlbear or bugbear.

- \<monster> eats a bear trap!

  A metallivore ate a bear trap.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

## References
